text.p: ** BIRTHDAYS **
British novelist FANNY BURNEY was born in 1752.
Irish poet, dramatist and co-founder of the Abbey Theatre in Dublin, WILLIAM BUTLER YEATS, was born in 1865.
German-born soprano ELIZABETH SCHUMANN was born in 1888.
South African-born actor BASIL RATHBONE, who played the character of Sherlock Holmes in 14 films, was born in 1892.
English writer of detective stories (and the creator of the aristocratic sleuth Lord Peter Wimsey), DOROTHY L. SAYERS, was born in 1893.
Australian artist SIR IVOR HELE was born in 1912.

Australian Labor politician FRED DALY was born in 1913. With an extenisve knowledge of parliamentary procedure and tactics, DALY always managed to make his comments and speeches enlightening and listenable.
The first Grand Slam winner in tennis, American DONALD BUDGE, was born in 1915.
Australian singer SLIM DUSTY (DAVID GORDON KIRKPATRICK) was born in 1927.
Australian singer/entertainer RED SIMONS ('Hey, Hey It's Saturday) was born in 1949.
** EVENTS **
This day was considered by unwed Portugese women as a good day to find out who their husbands would be. They would fill their mouths with water, and not let it out until they'd heard a man's name!
323 BC: ALEXANDER the Great who came to the throne at the age of 20 and conquered Persia, Egypt, Babylon, Central Asia and parts of India, died at the age of 33.
1774 : Rhode Island became the first American colony to ban the importation of slaves, and to assure their freedom.

1842 : QUEEN VICTORIA became the first British monarch to travel by train, when she took a trip from Slough to Paddington. 1893 : The first women's golf championship was held at Royal Lytham in Britain (won by MARGARET SCOTT).
1900 : The Boxer Rebellion began in China. The secret society was dedicated to ending the domination and exploitation of the country by foreigners.
1930 : British land and water speed record holder SIR HENRY SEGRAVE died when his speedboat capsized at 98 miles per hour (158 kph) on Lake Windermere in Northern England.

1931 : The return of long skirts was condemned by women as an infringement of their rights. The National Union of Societies for Equal Citizenship was told that when women's clothes get long and their legs are tied up, their minds will suffer. The meeting heard that it was no coincidence that when women gained freedom of dress they also gained freedom in politics.

1944 : London came under attack from the German V-1 flying bomb, known as the "doodle bug" (because of the sound the rocket made after it ran out of fuel and began to fall to earth). The rockets flew too fast to be accurately targetted by
anti-aircraft guns, leaving the British to stop the threat by attacking German launch sites.
1951 : Australian Labor Prime Minister JOSEPH BENEDICT (known as BEN) CHIFLEY died.
1956 : Real Madrid won the first European soccer cup in Paris, defeating Stade de Reims 4-3.
1956 : The last British troops left the Suez Canal Zone.
1962 : Sir EUGENE GOOSSENS, English composer and conductor, died. A member of a famed musical family, he spent his later years conducting in Australia where he trained many musicians.
1983 : The U.S. spacecraft Pioneer 10 crossed the orbit of Neptune and became the first man-made object to leave the solar system.

1986 : American clarinetist BENNY GOODMAN, known as the 'King of Swing" for the new jazz idiom her introduced with arranger FLETCHER HENDERSON, died. He introduced jazz to New York's Carnegie Hall in 1938, and was born on the 30th of May, 1909.
1988 : The first official beauty contest was held in the Soviet Union.
1989 : Soviet leader MIKHAIL GORBACHEV and German chancellor HELMUT KOHL agreed that East and West Germany should be reunited.
1990 : East Germany began the final demolition of the Berlin Wall, knocking out concrete slabs all over the city to re-open streets sealed off since the Cold War barrier was built in 1961.
1993 : Rockets fired by Serb forces killed more than 50 people in a makeshift hospital in the besieged Moslem enclave of Gorazde in eastern Bosnia.
1994 : North Korea announced it was withdrawing from the U.N.'s International Atomic Energy Agency and would no longer permit its inspectors into the country.
1996 : Copper prices tumbled around the world after Sumitomo Corp said it had lost an estimated $1.8 billion over 10 years from unauthorised copper trades.
1996 : The longest siege in U.S. federal history ended when 16 anti-government Freemen surrendered in Montana after 81 days.
